duties: Course Description: This class will survey some of the many music and dance traditions that can be seen and heard in a variety of Brazilian contexts. In addition to the most well-known of these, the carnival samba of Rio de Janeiro, the course explores lesser known but equally vital practices such as samba de roda, forro, and axe music. Each will be studied in relation to sound, bodily movement, and pertinent social issues such as cultural politics, nationalism, racial identity, and tourism, among others. Define course objectives and materials; provide clear guidelines on course requirements and regulations; teach classes; administer and evaluate student assignments; prepare and submit final grade in accordance with policy.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Doctoral study in ethnomusicology with preference to students advanced to PhD candidacy.

duties: As part of a joint Writing Instruction for TAs (WIT) and English Language Learning (ELL) Initiative in Arts and Science, the Lead TA will work with the WIT and ELL Coordinators to support Course Instructors and train regular course TAs in BCH311H1. The LTA will perform the following duties: Participate in group training sessions with the WIT program; 1:1 training with ELL coordinator ; Meet with WIT and ELL coordinators and course instructors to plan course assignments and tutorials; Design and lead training sessions for course TAs on topics such as marking assignments and presentations, as well as planning tutorial activities integrating BCH311 course content to scholarly reading, professional writing, oral presentation, discussion skills, and intercultural communication ; 	Develop and/or adapt existing resources on reading, oral presentation, and writing instruction for course instructors, TAs, and students ; Communicate regularly with course instructors, WIT and ELL coordinators, and others to coordinate activities ; Hours will include attendance at group WIT training sessions in Summer 2024 as well as individual meetings with WIT and ELL coordinators

job_title: Coping with Complexity in Persistent Illness (Adult)
application_procedure: "Please click on the "How to Apply" tab on our website: https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/careers/clinical-instructor-positions
duties:
The Lawrence Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing Program provides a full-time, two-year, second entry baccalaureate nursing education. Given that nursing is a practice-based profession, we believe that clinical experience is a vital and integral component of the curriculum, providing students with hands-on opportunities to actively apply classroom learning to ‘real life’ nursing practice under the supervision and support of a clinical teacher. Clinical Instructors (CIs) play an important role in facilitating student learning and providing excellent clinical learning experiences to further develop students’ knowledge, skill, and judgement. 
	
CIs should be flexible and prepared to utilize additional learning modalities such as simulation and virtual clinical learning in the event a clinical day is cancelled by the organization. CIs will work closely with the Clinical Education Office and Course Faculty to develop and share resources to support the continuity of clinical teaching and student learning. CIs are required to complete all on-boarding and orientation activities required by the faculty as well as the clinical placement site prior to the start of the placement in preparation for their clinical teaching role. Ongoing support will be provided throughout the term by Course Faculty, the Undergraduate Clinical Resource Faculty, and the Clinical Education Office.  Applicants should note that commitment to the role for the entire term is needed for consistency in the development, assessment, and evaluation of nursing students.                                                   Duties and Responsibilities:                                                                                                                                                                                                                        1.	Complete the asynchronous CI orientation learning modules as required and attend the in-person Faculty-led CI orientation for NUR460.
2.	Complete all on-boarding and orientation required by the University as well as the clinical placement site prior to the first clinical shift.
3.	Familiarize themselves with and uphold all faculty and University policies related to clinical placements (e.g., CI and Student Absences, Professional Behaviour). 
4.	Prepare patient assignments prior to students' arrival on the nursing unit, reflective of the students' level of expertise.
5.	Assist with and assess the students' preparation for their clinical activities with attention to integration of nursing, pathophysiological, pharmacologic, and therapeutic concepts.
6.	Encourage an inquiring, theory, and evidence-based approach to nursing practice.
7.	Facilitate interprofessional  and intraprofessional communication among students and all members of the health care team.
8.	Supervise and assist students with providing nursing care while monitoring and assessing students’ progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations.
9.	Collaborate with nursing staff and other health care providers in gaining assistance and access to learning experiences for the students.
10.	Foster discussion and debate about clinical learning among students during post clinical conferences
11.	Participate in weekly email communication with Course Faculty and provide a brief update and/or identify any concerns about students’ experiences and clinical progress. 
12.	Provide students with ongoing verbal feedback about their progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the course. 
13.	Complete an online written final clinical evaluation of each student that highlights their learning and progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the clinical placement.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
"Qualifications:
1. Interest in clinical teaching and working with novice nursing students.
2. Minimum of 2-3 years of current and relevant clinical experience (acute care nursing).
3. Current registration with the College of Nurses of Ontario as a Registered Nurse or Registered Nurse in the Extended Class. 
4. BScN required; MN will be considered an asset.
5. Previous experience in clinical instructing or as a preceptor is an asset.

Note to Graduate Students:
If you are a graduate student and you accept the position, you will agree to the following:

job_title: Coping with Complexity in Persistent Illness (Pediatric)
application_procedure: "Please click on the "How to Apply" tab on our website: https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/careers/clinical-instructor-positions
duties:
The Lawrence Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing Program provides a full-time, two-year, second entry baccalaureate nursing education. Given that nursing is a practice-based profession, we believe that clinical experience is a vital and integral component of the curriculum, providing students with hands-on opportunities to actively apply classroom learning to ‘real life’ nursing practice under the supervision and support of a clinical teacher. Clinical Instructors (CIs) play an important role in facilitating student learning and providing excellent clinical learning experiences to further develop students’ knowledge, skill, and judgement. 
	
CIs should be flexible and prepared to utilize additional learning modalities such as simulation and virtual clinical learning in the event a clinical day is cancelled by the organization. CIs will work closely with the Clinical Education Office and Course Faculty to develop and share resources to support the continuity of clinical teaching and student learning. CIs are required to complete all on-boarding and orientation activities required by the faculty as well as the clinical placement site prior to the start of the placement in preparation for their clinical teaching role. Ongoing support will be provided throughout the term by Course Faculty, the Undergraduate Clinical Resource Faculty, and the Clinical Education Office.  Applicants should note that commitment to the role for the entire term is needed for consistency in the development, assessment, and evaluation of nursing students.                                 Duties and Responsibilities:                  1.	Complete the asynchronous CI orientation learning modules as required and attend the in-person Faculty-led CI orientation for NUR460.
2.	Complete all on-boarding and orientation required by the University as well as the clinical placement site prior to the first clinical shift.
3.	Familiarize themselves with and uphold all faculty and University policies related to clinical placements (e.g., CI and Student Absences, Professional Behaviour). 
4.	Prepare patient assignments prior to students' arrival on the nursing unit, reflective of the students' level of expertise.
5.	Assist with and assess the students' preparation for their clinical activities with attention to integration of nursing, pathophysiological, pharmacologic, and therapeutic concepts.
6.	Encourage an inquiring, theory, and evidence-based approach to nursing practice.
7.	Facilitate interprofessional  and intraprofessional communication among students and all members of the health care team.
8.	Supervise and assist students with providing nursing care while monitoring and assessing students’ progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations.
9.	Collaborate with nursing staff and other health care providers in gaining assistance and access to learning experiences for the students.
10.	Foster discussion and debate about clinical learning among students during post clinical conferences.
11.	Participate in weekly email communication  with Course Faculty and provide a brief update and/or identify any concerns about students’ experiences and clinical progress. 
12.	Provide students with ongoing verbal feedback about their progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the course. 
13.	Complete an online written final clinical evaluation of each student that highlights their learning and progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the clinical placement.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
"Qualifications:
1. Interest in clinical teaching and working with novice nursing students.
2. Minimum of 2-3 years of current and relevant clinical experience (acute care nursing - pediatric).
3. Current registration with the College of Nurses of Ontario as a Registered Nurse or Registered Nurse in the Extended Class. 
4. BScN required; MN will be considered an asset.
5. Previous experience in clinical instructing or as a preceptor is an asset.

Note to Graduate Students:
If you are a graduate student and you accept the position, you will agree to the following:
“I confirm that I will be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF on the date that this appointment begins. I understand that if I should cease to be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF during the period of this appointment, for any reason other than convocation, I must immediately notify my supervisor, and my appointment may be terminated.”

job_title: Introduction to Nursing in Health and Wellness – Older Person Nursing
application_procedure: "Please click on the "How to Apply" tab on our website: https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/careers/clinical-instructor-positions
duties:
The Lawrence Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing Program provides a full-time, two-year, second entry baccalaureate nursing education. Given that nursing is a practice-based profession, we believe that clinical experience is a vital and integral component of the curriculum, providing students with hands-on opportunities to actively apply classroom learning to ‘real life’ nursing practice under the supervision and support of a clinical teacher. Clinical Instructors (CIs) play an important role in facilitating student learning and providing excellent clinical learning experiences to further develop students’ knowledge, skill, and judgement. 
	
CIs should be flexible and prepared to utilize additional learning modalities such as simulation and virtual clinical learning in the event a clinical day is cancelled by the organization. CIs will work closely with the Clinical Education Office and Course Faculty to develop and share resources to support the continuity of clinical teaching and student learning. CIs are required to complete all on-boarding and orientation activities required by the faculty as well as the clinical placement site prior to the start of the placement in preparation for their clinical teaching role. Ongoing support will be provided throughout the term by Course Faculty, the Undergraduate Clinical Resource Faculty, and the Clinical Education Office.  Applicants should note that commitment to the role for the entire term is needed for consistency in the development, assessment, and evaluation of nursing students.                              Duties and Responsibilities:                 1.	Complete the asynchronous CI orientation learning modules as required and attend the in-person Faculty-led CI orientation for NUR361.
2.	Complete all on-boarding and orientation required by the University as well as the clinical placement site prior to the first clinical shift.
3.	Familiarize themselves with and uphold all faculty and University policies related to clinical placements (e.g., CI and Student Absences, Professional Behaviour). 
4.	Prepare patient assignments prior to students’ arrival on the nursing unit, reflective of the students’ level of expertise.
5.	Facilitate students’ application of theory related to foundational therapeutic, relational, and health assessment skills.
Note: Students are expected to apply learning from the classroom and lab settings each week during their clinical shifts. This is done through practising the learned assessments and skills as part of the nursing care provided, as well as engaging in active discussions about the learning with the CI and clinical group. 
6.	Assist with and assess the students’ preparation for their clinical activities with attention to integration of nursing, pathophysiological, and therapeutic concepts.
7.	Encourage an inquiring, theory, and evidence-informed approach to nursing practice.
8.	Facilitate interprofessional and intraprofessional communication among students and all members of the health care team.
9.	Directly supervise and assist students as they relate to and provide care for older persons, while also monitoring and assessing students’ progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations. 
10.	Collaborate with nursing staff in gaining assistance and access to learning experiences for the students.
11.	Foster reflection and critical discussion about clinical learning among students during conferences.
12.	Participate in weekly email communication with Course Faculty and provide a brief update and/or identify any concerns about students’ experiences and clinical progress. 
13.	Provide students with ongoing verbal feedback about their progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the course. 
14.	Provide a written final online evaluation incorporating feedback from all clinical shifts.
15.	Arrange and facilitate a short 1:1 virtual meeting to review each students’ final evaluation within a week of the final clinical shift.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
"Qualifications:
1. Interest in clinical teaching and working with novice nursing students.
2. Minimum of 2-3 years of current and relevant clinical experience (long term care/older person care/adult acute care nursing).
3. Current registration with the College of Nurses of Ontario as a Registered Nurse or Registered Nurse in the Extended Class. 
4. BScN required; MN will be considered an asset.
5. Previous experience in clinical instructing or as a preceptor is an asset.

Note to Graduate Students:
If you are a graduate student and you accept the position, you will agree to the following:
“I confirm that I will be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF on the date that this appointment begins. I understand that if I should cease to be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF during the period of this appointment, for any reason other than convocation, I must immediately notify my supervisor, and my appointment may be terminated.”

job_title: Invigilator, Services to Persons with a Disability
appointment_size: Hours of work are determined by the tests and examinations scheduled, therefore minimum/maximum hours cannot be guaranteed
application_procedure:
•  Complete application form before closing date (July 2nd at 11:59 PM). Applicants must be signed in to their UofT webmail account to access the form. 
• Application form link: https://forms.office.com/r/3EE17L1Xfv. If you are experiencing technical difficulties with the form, email accessexams.utsc@utoronto.ca to report the issues you are having
Applicants submit:
•  Resume is required; cover letter is optional
•  Responses to two supplementary questions (posted on application form).
•  University of Toronto student number and confirmation of registration status on ACORN
•  Confirmation of availability for the period outlined above
•  NOTE: Incomplete applications will not be considered
duties:
Incumbents will supervise the writing of tests and examinations written by students with documented disabilities who are registered with AccessAbility Services at the University of Toronto, Scarborough (UTSC). 
Responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the following: 
•Supervising in-person tests and examinations written by persons wwith disability-related accommodations; some remote shifts may be required
• Through active invigilation, maintain the integrity of tests and exams by adhering to departmental, academic faculty, and university policies and procedures
• Maintaining confidentiality and security of student and test/exam information
• Ensuring the provision of disability-related accommodations to students as authorized by AccessAbility Services
• Monitoring test/exam time allotments
• Handling student concerns/problems and referring to Test and Exam Coordinator where appropriate
• Documenting and responding to anomalous situations
• Preparing completed in-person tests/exams for return delivery 
• Verifying student identification
• Maintaining required administrative records
• Ensuring the physical exam space, including supply cabinet, Invigilator work station, and students' writing areas, are kept clean and organized
qualifications:
• Applicants must be currently registered as students pursuing a degree at the University of Toronto  
• Applicants must demonstrate a commitment to the principles of equity and inclusion 
• Applicants must be available for in-person invigilation shifts
• Preference will be given to candidates who have experience working with persons with disabilities
• Experience invigilating tests/exams is an asset
• First Aid and CPR certification is an asset
• Applicants are required to provide availability between the hours of 7:30 AM - 10:30 PM, Monday through Saturday
• A minimum of 10 hours of availability must be provided each week between Mondays - Fridays from 7:30 AM to 6 PM AND
• A minimum of 45 hours of availability must be provided during all final exam periods. N.B. Occasional Sunday shifts may also be required
Successful candidates must participate in mandatory training, which will consist of:
• September training sessions: more details to follow
• New Invigilators are required to participate in a minimum of 3 in-person shadow shifts prior to the examination period
• New Invigilators are required to participate in preliminary in-person independent shifts after completion of their shadow shifts
Please note that all aspects of training will be scheduled between 7:30 AM - 5:00 PM Monday through Saturday.
Successful candidates must attend three final exam meetings to be held the week before deferred and final exam period begins. The meetings will be scheduled between 8:30 AM – 5:00 PM, Mondays to Fridays.
• Ability to respond effectively to emergency, difficult or sensitive situations while maintaining appropriate boundaries
• Ability to demonstrate integrity and professionalism, while remaining calm under pressure
• Problem solving and resourcefulness
• Attention to details
• Situational awareness and the ability to manage changing priorities
• Understanding and ability to apply relevant University and government policies, procedures and legislation 
• Initiative
• Ability to collaborate with others and work in a team setting
• Organizational
• Communication (both oral and written)
• Strong computer skills, including MS Office; Experience with assistive technology and Zoom an asset
salery: $47.92/hr + $1/hr worked on Saturday and Sunday shifts + 4% vacation pay

job_title: Chemical Engineering and Applied Chemistry- Laboratory III
department: Department of Chemical Engineering and Applied Chemistry
application_procedure:
Please complete the TA Application Form: https://forms.office.com/r/sFKcKqSpzN

If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact ugradassist.chemeng@utoronto.ca
duties:
•	Prepare Quercus course website with laboratory/teaching materials provided from the existing laboratory lab manuals and course syllabus; maintain and monitor student submission activities, grading, and feedback. Note candidate is not expected to develop new course materials (i.e., laboratory manuals). However, adjustments / improvements to existing materials may be required to meet course learning outcomes. 
•	Become familiar with laboratory experiments and operational procedures. The candidate should be able to troubleshoot issues arrived from the experimentations (i.e., identify equipment issues with support of the technicians, identify issues from students’ experimental data/results) 
•	Interview, hire, and manage Teaching Assistants (TAs).  logistics and training. Equipment training is supported by the laboratory technician. The candidate is responsible for ensuring project concept and equipment operation competency.
•	Deliver laboratory sessions, including pre-laboratory presentations, project learning objectives, industrial relevancy/applications, and end-of-the-lab day/project wrap-up/debrief sessions. 
•	Supervise and assist students in all aspects related to the course, including in-lab sessions and post-lab concepts/design questions.
•	Assess students’ performance using the assessment tools as described in the course syllabus (quizzes, in-lab assessments, presentations, lab reports)
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates should be enrolled or should have made an application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies or a post-doctoral fellow at the University of Toronto with strong written and oral communication skills and demonstrated commitment to teaching. Candidates should hold a minimum bachelor's degree in Chemical Engineering or equivalent or closely related discipline. In addition, the candidate should have experience in process design, preferably having work experience in the chemical/production industry.
qualifications_preferred: In addition to the above minimum qualifications, successful applicants should demonstrate teaching and/or industrial experience in at least one of the following areas: Process modelling and Simulation, Energy/Oil and Gas, Renewable Energy, Catalysis, Environment, Water treatment, and Separation. Candidates with experience in process simulation and CAD software such as Aspen Plus, AutoDesk 2D/3D CAD drawing and CFD/ANSYS is highly desirable.
salery: $9,094.13 + vacation pay. If first CI appointment, $10,163.28 + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure: Applicants should submit a cover letter, CV, and a list of two referees to Liz Lourenco, Manager, Centre for Medieval Studies, by e-mail to manager.medieval@utoronto.ca by 11:59 p.m., Friday, June 21, 2024.
duties: Duties include course preparation and delivery of course content; designing and preparing tests, assignments, and exams; marking written and oral assignments, tests, and exams; calculating and submitting grades; holding regular office hours; and attending course administrative meetings as required.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

application_procedure: Please apply at the following link: https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=JsKqeAMvTUuQN7RtVsVSECltESPGA0ZGtYwlN1XD_fZUNTA5R0Q5TEJRQVoyV1UyNTlBN0lMNklGSy4u
duties: This job is for an instructor in a large undergraduate course with multiple sections.  The instructor will be a member of a coordinated team with a designated course coordinator.  Each instructor will perform tasks including but not limited to: lecturing, conducting office hours, preparing class materials / tutorials / tests / exams, grading assignments / exams, communicating with TAs.  The exact mix will be determined by the course coordinator and may change as the situation evolves. You are also expected to attend the orientation meetings and course organizational meetings. Additional duties may be required as directed by the Course Coordinator, the Undergraduate Administrator or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate. Normally, classes, tests and tutorials will be conducted in person.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior PhD student in mathematics (entered PhD) program in 2019, or earlier) or Current PDF with a PhD degree in Mathemtics working in Mathematics or a related field. Knowledge of course material, being responsible and able to keep deadlines are essential. Previous experience as a Course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset.

application_procedure: Please apply at the following link: https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=JsKqeAMvTUuQN7RtVsVSECltESPGA0ZGtYwlN1XD_fZUNTA5R0Q5TEJRQVoyV1UyNTlBN0lMNklGSy4u
duties: This job is for an instructor in a large undergraduate course with multiple sections which may or may not have a designated course coordinator.  Each instructor will perform tasks including but not limited to: lecturing, conducting office hours, preparing class materials / tutorials / tests / exams, grading assignments / exams, communicating with TAs.  The exact mix will be determined by the course coordinator (if applicable) and may change as the situation evolves. You are also expected to attend the orientation meetings and course organizational meetings.  Additional duties may be required as directed by the Course Coordinator (if applicable), the Undergraduate Administrator or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate.  If there is no designated coordinator, there is an expectation that the different sections of a multi-section course will function similarly: they will normally have the same syllabus and assessment plan, and will have common midterm exams and final exam. Problem sets and quizzes should be common, or at least similar/interchangeable, and should operate at a similar level with a similar approach.  In addition, all instructors are expected to work together with the other instructors in the course and to collaborate in creating the syllabus, determining the course structure, and creating and marking the final assessment.  Normally, classes, tests and tutorials will be conducted in person.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior PhD student in mathematics (entered PhD) program in 2019, or earlier) or Current PDF with a PhD degree in Mathemtics working in Mathematics or a related field. Knowledge of course material, being responsible and able to keep deadlines are essential. Previous experience as a Course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset.

Normally, classes, tests and tutorials will be conducted in person.

job_title: Calculus I for the Life Sciences
application_procedure: Applications accepted online https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/dept/cms/app/ta
duties: General duties include supporting the development of resources for the course, providing disciplinary knowledge to the collaboration and providing examples of models in the life sciences that can be treated with elementary mathematics. The TA will select exercises and modeling tasks suitable for the course which will foreshadow material that the students will actually encounter in their life science courses. Their direct experience with the life sciences curriculum will be essential to ensure that the materials produced are relevant to students in future courses in the life sciences. Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position. Must be comfortable preparing documents in LaTeX. The student must be in 3rd or 4th year with extensive background in life sciences. These paid positions are open only to University of Toronto students who have demonstrated a sound knowledge of the relevant subject matter and who have the ability to impart that knowledge to other students. All contracts are by session and extend for four months each as per the length of each session.
qualifications_preferred: N/A

application_procedure: Apply online at: https://tapp.cs.toronto.edu/hash/public/postings/M2kahFpkFD3u1sy7cne8wwY6 ; For inquiries, contact: tacoord@cs.toronto.edu
duties: Duties will be primarily marking, hosting group discussions, mentoring students on their research publication, and meeting/emailing with the professor for guidance and to get feedback. TA responsibilities involve giving feedback to three homeworks on writing research, which also have a peer-review component, taking attendance, and office hours (or communication) with students.  Classes take place in the evenings of Tuesdays and Thursdays  6-9pm from the period of August 19-October 7; and some availability is required during this time period to host group discussions.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: The chosen candidate(s) must be familiar with academic and scientific writing and have publication experience. Ideally, the incumbent will have knowledge and experience of writing and revising drafts of research papers, crafting research abstracts and titles, conducting literature reviews and experiments, creating figures and tables, presenting research (i.e. poster and oral presentations), and the submission and review process. The incumbent should demonstrate maturity and have strong English writing and oral communication/presentation skills. Previous TA experience is an asset.
qualifications_preferred: see minimum qualifications

duties:
This job is for an instructor in a large undergraduate course with multiple sections which may or may not have a designated course coordinator.  Each instructor will perform tasks including but not limited to: lecturing, conducting office hours, preparing class materials / tutorials / tests / exams, grading assignments / exams, communicating with TAs.  The exact mix will be determined by the course coordinator (if applicable) and may change as the situation evolves. You are also expected to attend the orientation meetings and course organizational meetings.  Additional duties may be required as directed by the Course Coordinator (if applicable), the Undergraduate Administrator or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate.
 
If there is no designated coordinator, there is an expectation that the different sections of a multi-section course will function similarly: they will normally have the same syllabus and assessment plan, and will have common midterm exams and final exam. Problem sets and quizzes should be common, or at least similar/interchangeable, and should operate at a similar level with a similar approach.  In addition, all instructors are expected to work together with the other instructors in the course and to collaborate in creating the syllabus, determining the course structure, and creating and marking the final assessment.  Normally, classes, tests and tutorials will be conducted in person.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior PhD student in mathematics (entered PhD) program in 2019, or earlier) or Current PDF with a PhD degree in Mathemtics working in Mathematics or a related field. Knowledge of course material, being responsible and able to keep deadlines are essential. Previous experience as a Course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset.

qualifications_minimum: Successful applicants will have experience working on a crime scene following proper forensic protocols for establishing perimeters, safe zones, search strategies, recovering evidence, etc.; familiarity with biohazard protocols relating to decomposed and/or diseased tissues; completed or TA'ed undergraduate courses in forensic anthropology, osteology and archaeology. Must be available for 8 hours each day on UTM campus Monday-Friday from August 6-16, 2024.

job_title: Finance Review for MFI: Web Modules
application_procedure:
Application information is available at https://www.statistics.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cupe-positions-unit-1. Applicants should submit a cover letter, C.V. (including previous teaching evaluations (if applicable)), and two references by June 5, 2024. Applications should be sent to:

Angela Niazmand
Department of Statistical Sciences
            700 University Avenue
Room 9160-6
          Toronto, Ontario, M5G 1Z5
E-mail: jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca
duties:
The instructor will prepare and teach 6-7 modules of 2 hours each that will be recorded and posted on Quercus by the 1st of July 2024. The material covered will be: theory of mathematical finance and stochastic calculus. Examination: there will be a final project. Students will be required to do a presentation in groups. 

Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George campus.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Master’s or PhD (in progress) degree in Mathematical Finance, Actuarial Science. Statistics or related discipline. Prior experience teaching at the university level. Note: Applicants may be asked to supply references. First consideration will be given to full-time graduate students at the University of Toronto.
qualifications_preferred: Master’s or PhD (in progress) degree in Mathematical Finance, Actuarial Science. Statistics or related discipline. Prior experience teaching at the university level. Note: Applicants may be asked to supply references. First consideration will be given to full-time graduate students at the University of Toronto.
tutorial: Meeting Schedule: 				Online web modules; Lectures will be posted by 1st of July 2024

application_procedure: Fill out application form found here (https://moleculargenetics.utoronto.ca/teaching-assistantships-ta) and send CV to studentservices.mogen@utoronto.ca
duties: Formative feedback for students on course assignments, in consultation with the course coordinator. Marking laboratory reports & submitted assignments. Assist Instructors in the development of tutorials and assignments.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications: Applicants will be considered on the basis of their familiarity with bioinformatics practices in the molecular biology research lab using the R Programming language & must have completed undergraduate training in this area, or have gained equivalent experience through research project work.  Further details about the Department’s hiring policy are available in the Department & the CUPE office.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants will be considered on the basis of their familiarity with bioinformatics practices in the molecular biology research lab using the R Programming language & must have completed undergraduate training in this area, or have gained equivalent experience through research project work.  Further details about the Department’s hiring policy are available in the Department & the CUPE office.

application_procedure: Please apply at the following link: https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=JsKqeAMvTUuQN7RtVsVSECltESPGA0ZGtYwlN1XD_fZUNTA5R0Q5TEJRQVoyV1UyNTlBN0lMNklGSy4u
duties: This job is for an instructor in a large undergraduate course with multiple sections which may or may not have a designated course coordinator.  Each instructor will perform tasks including but not limited to: lecturing, conducting office hours, preparing class materials / tutorials / tests / exams, grading assignments / exams, communicating with TAs.  The exact mix will be determined by the course coordinator (if applicable) and may change as the situation evolves. You are also expected to attend the orientation meetings and course organizational meetings.  Additional duties may be required as directed by the Course Coordinator (if applicable), the Undergraduate Administrator or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate.  If there is no designated coordinator, there is an expectation that the different sections of a multi-section course will function similarly: they will normally have the same syllabus and assessment plan, and will have common midterm exams and final exam. Problem sets and quizzes should be common, or at least similar/interchangeable, and should operate at a similar level with a similar approach.  In addition, all instructors are expected to work together with the other instructors in the course and to collaborate in creating the syllabus, determining the course structure, and creating and marking the final assessment.  Normally, classes, tests and tutorials will be conducted in person.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior PhD student in mathematics (entered PhD) program in 2019, or earlier) or Current PDF with a PhD degree in Mathemtics working in Mathematics or a related field. Knowledge of course material, being responsible and able to keep deadlines are essential. Previous experience as a Course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset.

job_title: Calculus and Linear Algebra for Commerce
application_procedure: Please apply at the following link: https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=JsKqeAMvTUuQN7RtVsVSECltESPGA0ZGtYwlN1XD_fZUNTA5R0Q5TEJRQVoyV1UyNTlBN0lMNklGSy4u
duties: This job is for an instructor in a large undergraduate course with multiple sections. In this position, you will be a member of a coordinated instructional team, with a designated course coordinator. This course is taught in an active-learning style. Your duties may include but are not limited to: preparing and facilitating lecture activities, holding office hours, attending meetings, communicating with TAs, engaging in professional development, co-authoring guides for the instructional team, designing class materials and assessments, grading, and/or creating other student supports. The exact mix of duties will be determined by the course coordinator.  Normally, classes, tests and tutorials will be conducted in person.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior PhD student in mathematics (entered PhD) program in 2019, or earlier) or Current PDF with a PhD degree in Mathemtics working in Mathematics or a related field. Knowledge of course material, being responsible and able to keep deadlines are essential. Previous experience as a Course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset.

experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: The successful candidate will hold ASLTA or ASL Instructor certification (or equivalent) and have knowledge of Deaf culture and/or lived experience with a Deaf community. Documentation of native or near-native fluency in ASL is required; scores should be submitted from an ASL Language Proficiency Interview (ASLPI) or other assessment conducted by a qualified organization (e.g. the Canadian Cultural Society of the Deaf, Gallaudet University, or the ASLTA). Evidence of prior successful teaching of ASL must be submitted along with the application (teaching evaluations, sample syllabi, etc.).
qualifications_preferred: A Master's or PhD in a relevant field is preferred. Previous experience working with Teaching Assistants/Graders is desirable. Excellent teaching evaluations and relevant active research are an asset.

job_title: Data Analytics with Financial Accounting Information
application_procedure: For detailed information on the application procedure go to  http://www-2.rotman.utoronto.ca/employment/tapositions/
duties:
Course Summary: 
 This course introduces the analytical mindset and data analytics skills that accounting professionals need to analyze and evaluate a variety of data in order to create insights for making decisions. In particular, you will learn to ask the right questions, prepare the relevant data, apply the appropriate data analytics methods, and interpret the results to answer the questions. You will also learn to use common data analytics tools, such as Excel, Access (SQL), and Tableau to prepare, analyze, and model financial data. Finally, you will apply the analytical mindset and data analytics skills to address various accounting, finance, and general business problems.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: An advanced graduate degree is required – PhD/in progress PhD.; candidates should either have a PhD or have made substantial progress towards getting their PhD. Candidates should have strong technical skills and knowledge of accounting, economics, statistics and econometrics. Candidates should also have mastery over data modeling and data analytics and familiarity with he use of Excel, Access and Tableau for these applications.
qualifications_preferred: N/A

application_procedure: Applications should be made with an academic CV and cover letter via the TAships website (https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/lin) by the posted deadline. duties: Grading of assignments, tests, and the final exam, and teaching (remotely) of weekly tutorials. Note: The mode of instruction for this course is ONLINE SYNCHRONOUS.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Demonstrated ability in the specific area of the course (formal linguistic analysis of English grammar; i.e., from a theoretical linguistic perspective) is required.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate-level research in theoretical linguistics is preferred. Graduate-level research in the specific subject area of this course is preferred. Experience in this course or a similar course is preferred.
tutorial: Thursdays at various times (Please see https://ttb.utoronto.ca/) [ONLINE SYNCHRONOUS]

application_procedure: Please visit https://ecp.engineering.utoronto.ca/job-opportunities/application-procedures-cupe-unit-1-positions/ for details on the application procedure.
duties:
-Upload names to DELNA
-Get and upload updated First Year lists
-Download after each sitting and maintain a running spreadsheet that separates EngSci and Core 8/Track 1 students, sorts by Band, identifies students with a ≥40% difference between vocabulary and reading scores
-Clean up spreadsheet to eliminate duplicate and incomplete attempts
-Maintain a completion list that includes email addresses and required categories using VLOOKUPS
-Send reminders at the end of each week to students who have not yet completed the screening
-Send personalized results letters at the end of each week
-Workload will be heavier in September - Must be readily available to generate updated spreadsheets by Sept 10th.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates should be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies, University of Toronto, or should have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies, University of Toronto, in an appropriate discipline (such as, but not limited to, Communication, English, Engineering, Education, Technology Studies) with strong data analysis skills, ability to work with EXCEL or similar programs.
qualifications_preferred: Candidates should be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies, University of Toronto, or should have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies, University of Toronto, in an appropriate discipline (such as, but not limited to, Communication, English, Engineering, Education, Technology Studies) with strong data analysis skills, ability to work with EXCEL or similar programs.
salery: $51.93 per hour + vacation pay (as of Jan 1, 2024). Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure:
1. Submit applications on-line through the TA system:  https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/ant/login
2. Please submit a writing sample (individually authored and no more than four pages) by June 21, 2024 to Josie Alaimo through email to: josie.alaimo@utoronto.ca.
duties: * The applicant must be available for approximately 25 hours of training and preparatory work (e.g., consultations with WIT coordinators, contacts, and course instructors) throughout July and August. Mandatory training sessions will be held online from July 23 to 25, 2024, and in-person on August 28, 2024. All training sessions are held from 1:00 to 4:00 pm Eastern.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
• Current PhD student with least two years' experience as a course TA, whether leading tutorials/ labs, in-class instruction, or grading
• Excellent oral communication and interpersonal skills, particularly the ability to work effectively with and show tact when communicating with administrators, course instructors, and TAs
• Strong administrative skills, including ability to schedule meetings and training sessions, plan and document work
• Strong time management skills with ability to meet multiple deadlines
• Strong facilitation and presentation skills and/or experience leading/facilitating workshops
• Evidence of superior writing skills in their discipline
• Flexible schedule, willing and able to accommodate short notice requests for meetings with WIT staff, course instructors, and TAs

application_procedure: Submit cover letter, resume, and course list by email to test.exam@utoronto.ca.
duties:
To be considered for this appointment, applicants must have demonstrated prior experience working as an Invigilator at Accommodated Testing Services, University of Toronto, St. George Campus in the 2023-2024 academic year.

Incumbents will supervise the writing tests and examinations written by students with documented disabilities who are registered with Accessibility Services at the University of Toronto, St. George Campus.

Responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the following:
--Maintaining the integrity of tests and exams by adhering to departmental, academic faculty, and university policies and procedures
--Maintaining confidentiality of student and test/exam information
--Ensuring the provision of accommodations to students as specified by Accessibility Services
--Monitoring test/exam time allotments
--Handling student concerns/problems and escalating to the Coordinator, Accommodated Testing Services, as needed.
--Documenting and responding to anomalous situations
--Preparing completed tests/exams for return delivery
--Maintaining required administrative records

Hours of work are determined by the tests and examinations scheduled, therefore minimum/maximum hours cannot be guaranteed. The test centre is open from 7:00 AM to 11:00 PM and applicants are required to provide availability between the hours of 7:00 AM and 11:00 PM, Monday to Friday with a minimum of 10 hours of availability each week. Applicants are expected to provide a high level of availability during final exam periods in December and April. Please outline your availability in your cover letter.
qualifications:
To be considered for this appointment, applicants must have demonstrated prior experience working as an Invigilator at Accommodated Testing Services, University of Toronto, St. George Campus in the 2023-2024 academic year.

Successful applicants must be eligible for CUPE 3902 Unit 1 work and are expected to maintain their eligibility through the duration of the appointment. Any status change must be communicated to the Department, to determine eligibility to continue in the appointment.

Applicants must be available for the following mandatory in-person training session: Friday, September 20, 1-5pm.

This is an on-campus, in-person position. Applicants must be available for in-person invigilation shifts.

Applicants must demonstrate a commitment to the principles of equity and inclusion.

Skills (listed alphabetically):
•	Ability to manage and resolve emergency, difficult or sensitive situations effectively while maintaining boundaries
•	Ability to remain calm under pressure 
•	Communication (both oral and written)
•	Initiative
•	Interpersonal  
•	Organizational
•	Problem solving
•	Situational awareness and the ability to manage changing priorities
•	Strong computer skills including MS Office (Word, Excel, and Teams) and Zoom
•	Understanding and ability to apply relevant University and government policies, procedures and legislation
Candidates who are members of Indigenous, Black, racialized and LGBTQ2S+ communities, persons with disabilities, and other equity seeking groups are encouraged to apply

duties: Course preparation / Lecturing 4 hours per week / Providing scheduled in-person office hours for academic counselling of students (2 hours per week) / Attending pre-term instructor meeting before class starts / Attending coordination meetings & regularly corresponding with coordinator / Designing tests and exams / Invigilating tests & exams / Grading assignments, tests & exams
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.

The LWTA will perform the following duties:
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
• Current PhD student with least two years' experience as a course TA, whether leading tutorials/ labs, in-class instruction, or grading
• Excellent oral communication and interpersonal skills, particularly the ability to work effectively with and show tact when communicating with administrators, course instructors, and TAs
• Strong administrative skills, including ability to schedule meetings and training sessions, plan and document work
• Strong time management skills with ability to meet multiple deadlines
• Strong facilitation and presentation skills and/or experience leading/facilitating workshops
• Evidence of superior writing skills in their discipline

• Graduate-level knowledge across multiple subfields of theoretical linguistics
qualifications_preferred:
Previous experience as a TA in any linguistics WIT course
Previous experience as a Lead WIT TA in linguistics

Along with your application, if you have not been a Lead WIT TA before, please also submit a sample of your written linguistics work and/or evidence of experience/ability with designing writing materials/activities for teaching writing in LIN courses (rubrics, assignments, tutorial activities, etc.).

application_procedure: Submit a letter of application, a brief Statement of Teaching Philosophy, and a current CV to Aphrodite Gardner, Centre for Comparative Literature aphrodite.gardner@utoronto.ca
duties: The TA will conduct two weekly tutorial sections, hold regular office hours, meet periodically with the instructor, and mark student essays.  The TA will also keep a record of student progress, which will be used by the instructor to help determine final marks.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: At least two years of previous experience as a Teaching Assistant in position(s) involving tutorials or as a Course Instructor. Evidence of effective teaching and communication skills. Knowledge of some of the literature in the original language is a preferred qualification.
qualifications_preferred: MA in Comparative Literature or a closely related discipline.  Demonstrated knowledge of critical and literary Theory relevant to the course.  Scholarly expertise relevant to the course material (as shown, for example, by dissertation research).   What is colonialism and how is it related to "empires?"  Why and how are the European empires that developed in the early modern period so often associated with “race” and racialization? In this course we will explore the early stages of European colonialism and the long-term impact of the transformations it inaugurated. The rise of Portuguese, Spanish, English, French, and U.S. empires will be studied by readings from a variety of literary texts. We will also discuss many other issues that relate to Euro-colonialism such as capitalism, gender, modes of violence and militarism, together with forms of resistance against colonial rule.  Students will acquire a strong set of interpretative and writing skills, will learn to situate the literature we discuss in a broad, historical framework, and will be encouraged to think critically about contemporary manifestations of the issues we take up.  Method of evaluation:  One short essay (10%); One mid-term test (15%); One longer essay (25%); Tutorial and General Participation (25); End-of-term take-home exam (25%).  Qualifications required:  MA in Comparative Literature or a closely related discipline.  Demonstrated knowledge of critical and literary theory relevant to the course.  Scholarly expertise relevant to the course material (as shown, for example, by dissertation research).  At least two years of previous experience as a Teachng Assistant in position(s) involving tutorials or as a Course Instructor.  Evidence of effective teaching and communication skills.  Knowledge of some of the literature in the original language is a preferred qualification.

application_procedure: Submit a letter of application, a brief Statement of Teaching Philosophy, and a current CV to Aphrodite Gardner, Centre for Comparative Literature aphrodite.gardner@utoronto.ca
duties: The TA will conduct two weekly tutuorial sections, hold regular office hours, meet periodically with the instructor, and mark student essays.  The TA will also keep a record of student progress, which will be used by the instructor to help determine final marks.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: At least two years of previous experience as a Teaching Assistant in position(s) involving tutorials or as a Course Instructor. Evidence of effective teaching and communication skills. Knowledge of some of the literature in the original language is a preferred qualification.
qualifications_preferred:
MA in Comparative Literature or a closely related discipline.  Demonstrated knowledge of critical and literary Theory relevant to the course.  Scholarly expertise relevant to the course material (as shown, for example, by dissertation research). The principal focus of this course is the complex engagement of literature and the arts with both colonial and neo-colonial encounters between, Europe, Africa and the Americas over the last five hundred years. Exploring world cultures through the prism of colonial encounters facilitates discussions about the genesis of contemporary politics of globalisation as well as the accompanying dynamics of exploitation and resistance. This approach will also help to elucidate the ways in which contact between different world zones have been pivotal in the development of new national and regional cultures. In the process we engage with a wide range of questions including environmental precarity, food security, cultural violence, religious alterity, revolutions, and the coming of age of new subjectivities.   The material to be discussed will be organized under four broad headings: The Columbian Exchange in Cinema and Art; Colonial Encounters and Latin American Politics of Identity; Fictions of Colonial Encounters in West Africa; Narratives of Colonial and Neo-Colonial Encounters in the Caribbean. 

Primary texts may include works by
Miguel de Cervantes, Juan Rulfo, Octaivo Paz, Carlos Fuentes, William Shakespeare, Joseph Conrad, Chinua Achebe, Chimamanda Ngozi Adiche, Ama Ata Aidoo, Derek Walcott, Earl Lovelace, Olive Senior, Jaime Manrique and Anthony Winkler.

application_procedure: Submit a letter of application, a brief Statement of Teaching Philosophy, and a current CV to Aphrodite Gardner, Centre for Comparative Literature aphrodite.gardner@utoronto.ca
duties: The TA will conduct two weekly tutuorial sections, hold regular office hours, meet periodically with the instructor, and mark student essays and quizzes.  The TA will also keep a record of student progress, which will be used by the instructor to help determine final marks.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: At least two years of previous experience as a Teaching Assistant in position(s) involving tutorials or as a Course Instructor. Evidence of effective teaching and communication skills. Knowledge of some of the literature in the original language is a preferred qualification.
qualifications_preferred:
MA in Comparative Literature or a closely related discipline.  Demonstrated knowedge of the critical and litrary theory relevant to the course materials (as shown, for example, by dissertation research).  This course explores representation as a cultural and political problem.  Representation is both a means of depicting or constructing reality and a means of constituting individual and collective subjectivities.  We will consider literary and other modes of representation in their historical contexts.

Texts will span a broad historical range and may include: Homer’s The Odyssey, excerpts from the Bible and the Koran, Aristotle’s Poetics, Dante’s Inferno, portions of Auerbach’s Figura, Eliot's The Waste Land, Barthes's Mythologies, Mahasweta Devi's Imaginary Maps, and Foucault's The History of Sexuality, vol 1.

duties: As part of an English Language Learning (ELL) Initiative in Arts and Science, the Lead TA will work with the ELL Coordinator to support Course Instructors and train regular course TAs in selected courses. The ELL Lead TA will perform the following duties: Participate in training sessions with ELL faculty during the summer, as well as additional training sessions throughout the year; Meet in the summer with ELL Coordinator and ELL course instructors to plan course assignments and tutorials; Design and lead training sessions and consultations for course TAs (on topics such as responding to and grading assignments, planning tutorial related to scholarly reading, etc.) through Fall and Winter terms; Develop and/or adapt resources on language and writing instruction (such as marking rubrics and assignment guides) for course instructors, TAs, and students; Communicate regularly with ELL course instructors, ELL Coordinator, and others to coordinate activities; Collect data (e.g., surveys, student writing samples, etc.); Document activities (e.g., unit goals, monthly updates, write a final a report about the initiative’s impact in the unit, etc.)
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

qualifications_preferred: Current EAS PhD student with previous experience (at least two years' experience as a course TA in EAS's core courses (EAS103H1, EAS105H1, and/or EAS209H1), including leading tutorials); Excellent oral and interpersonal skills, particularly the ability to work effectively with and show tact when communicating with course instructors and TAs; Strong administrative skills, including scheduling meetings and planning, time management, meeting multiple deadlines, and documenting work; Able to prioritize tasks; Strong facilitation and presentation skills and/or experience leading workshops; Evidence of superior writing skills in their discipline; Flexible schedule, able to accommodate short notice requests for meetings.

qualifications_preferred: GPA above 3.5 in courses in visual communication.

duties: In this course, TA will assist instructor in guiding students through their selection of disciplinary frameworks, audio/visual material, and scholarly references in order to properly document and address a site condition. TA will annotate and grade a series of assignments that aim at processing the documentation and culminate in a research report. In the latter, TA will assess how students articulate together literature review, audio/visual documentation, methodology, and related design program/research questions in response to site-specific worldviews.

job_title: Advanced Urban Research Project: Health and Food Justice in Toronto During the COVID-19 Pandemic
application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter and curriculum vitae by 11:59pm EST on the closing date to hr.innis@utoronto.ca. The subject line should include the position title and the course code. For filing purposes, we ask that applicants applying to multiple positions please send separate emails for each position you are applying to.
duties: The Course Instructor will develop a detailed syllabus, teach the full course, conduct all grading and prepare and submit all final marks. In addition, the Course Instructor will hold office hours each week and answer student questions by email and/or appointment. | Course description: This course is an opportunity to be directly involved with an ongoing, multidisciplinary research project (funded by the Trans-Atlantic Partnership) examining community-based actions related to theCOVID-19 pandemic. The COVID-19 pandemic has deepened existing social, health and nutritional inequities and highlighted common challenges facing marginalized and racialized communities in cities across the Global North and South. It has also driven new social innovations and cross-sector collaborations, some of which may have the potential to transform the longstanding inequities that undermine global health, food systems and governance processes. Through this course, you will learn from the Toronto team of researchers from Urban Studies, Public Health and International Development Studies as well as our community partners. You will gain training in qualitative case study and community-based research methodologies, and you will contribute to the research through the development of a case study using the methods taught in the course. We hope to provide the opportunity for some students to present their course projects to the international research team after the course concludes.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: MA in related field • At least 3 years of experience teaching at the university level • At least 3 years of experience marking undergraduate essays • Evidence of recent teaching effectiveness • Ability to teach online if required
qualifications_preferred: PhD in progress
salery: $9,442.98 (excluding vacation pay) or $10,553.15 if first CI appointment (excluding vacation pay)

application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter, CV, and the contact information for two references to typ.office@utoronto.ca by May 31, 2024  at 5 PM.
duties:
The Introduction to Indigenous Studies seminar is designed to support TYP
students enrolled in INS201Y1 to identify key information in lecture and provide a thorough
understanding of course material and assignments. The seminar will further explore ideas, methods
and themes of the discipline of Indigenous Studies. The development of the field of Indigenous
Studies in Canada will form an important focus in the first half. The second part of the course will
address “history and politics,” including an overview of the historical processes of diplomacy,
alliances, and treaty-making. The duties of this position includes referencing the INS201Y1 syllabus to instruct and help students learn while providing an encouraging, creative, and positive environment for academic assistance for a variety of learning needs. Preparation and presentation of course materials and assignments for seminars  to help students succeed in academic writing for social science, history, and critical theory. Counsel students with respect to academic progress such as study-skills, academic reading, organization, and time management and assist them in obtaining appropriate counseling for non-academic matters. Evaluate attendance and course participation for the course. Attending scheduled faculty and staff meetings. Submitting marks for assessments associated with TYP053Y1.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants must be  Graduate Students enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto or those who have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto. Preference will be given to applicants engaged in research in Indigenous Studies. Applicants must have experience teaching INS201Y1 content and in-depth knowledge of Transitional YearProgramme (TYP) student supports, curriculum, and culture. Applicants must demonstrate a commitment to equity and anti-oppressive/social-justice approaches to education. Familiarity with Quercus and online/remote instructional methods is also an advantage.
qualifications_preferred:
Applicants must have previous work experience, and/or coursework relating to anti-oppression
and/or social-justice approaches to post-secondary education, knowledge
of/experience with adult education and the University of Toronto, and  experience advising students and providing academic support. In depth knowledge of the University
of Toronto community and University of Toronto student experience is an asset.

application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter, CV, and the contact information for two references to typ.office@utoronto.ca by May 31, 2024  at 5 PM.
duties: The Teaching Assistant will support the course instructor in the instruction and management of TYP014 (Introduction to University Studies), a core course of the Transitional Year Program at University of Toronto. This course aims to help students develop and strengthen the academic and life skills required to succeed as university students. It will include presentations on and practice in time management, note taking, study skills, essay writing, and preparation for examinations. In addition, it will deal with important matters for supporting mature students such as financial aid and how to get it, balancing study with family obligations, paid labour and other life contingencies, effective use of major student services, and techniques for dealing with the stresses and complications of academic life. The Teaching Assistant (TA) will support the course instructor in the general instruction and management of the course. The TA will help to lead a classes that support TYP students in their development of academic and life skills, including note-taking, the writing process, research, organization, and other related skills. The TA will evaluate student work, provide feedback, schedule and hold office hours,  provide academic support for course assignments, and lead discussions, and manage the course Quercus. Additional duties will be determined in consultation with the course instructor and registrar. The TA may be required to attend seminars, lectures, and meetings. Please note, this course will be offered in person, with online elements (i.e. Quercus). For more information about TYP, please visit typ.utoronto.ca.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: The candidate should be purusing a graduate or undergraduate degree in Education, Social Work, or a related discipline. Preference in hiring shall be given to Graduate Students enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto or those who have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto. The candidate must demonstrate a commitment to equity and anti-oppressive/social-justice approaches to education and familiarity with Quercus and online instructional methods.
qualifications_preferred: The candidate must have previous work experience and/ or coursework relating to educational access, anti-oppression, and social-justice approaches to post-secondary education. In-depth knowledge of the University of Toronto community and student experience. Knowledge of/ or experience with adult education and the University of Toronto Transitional Year Program or similar programming.                                 Experience advising students and providing writing support in the social sciences and/ or humanities.                                     Shortlisted candidates may be asked to complete a brief written screening question and/or an interview.

job_title: English Composition and Introduction to Academic Writing
application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter, CV, and the contact information for two references to typ.office@utoronto.ca by May 31, 2024  at 5 PM.
duties: The Teaching Assistant (TA)  will support the course instructor in the instruction and management of TYP006 (English Composition) and WRR103 (Introduction to Academic Writing). Both are core English courses at Transitional Year Programme at University of Toronto. These courses aim to improve students' confidence and abilities in expressing themselves and have the objective of equipping them to write university-level assignments. The courses also aim to improve students’ reading and analytic skills. The TA will support the course instructor in the general instruction and management of the courses. Duties range from grading and providing academic support for course assignments to holding consultation (office) hours and facilitating tutorials/ study groups; and from invigilating tests and exams to managing a variety of course-related clerical duties (e.g. updating content on Quercus). Additional duties will be determined in consultation with the course instructor and registrar. The TA may be required to attend seminars and lectures (asynchronous option available) and attend meetings. The courses are delivered in person with the possibility for online elements to be hosted on the University learning platform (Quercus). For more information about TYP, please visit typ.utoronto.ca.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: The candidate should be pursuing a graduate degree in English or a related discipline. Preference in hiring shall be given to Graduate Students enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies at the University of Toronto or to those who have applied to the School of Graduate Studies at the University of Toronto. The candidate must demonstrate a commitment to a) equity and anti-oppressive/ social-justice approaches to education and b) familiarity with Quercus and online instructional methods
qualifications_preferred: The candidate must have previous work experience and/ or coursework relating to educational access, anti-oppression, and social-justice approaches to post-secondary education. In-depth knowledge of the University of Toronto community and student experience is preferred. Knowledge of/ or experience with adult education and the University of Toronto Transitional Year Programme or similar programming is an asset.  Experience advising students and providing writing support in the social sciences and/ or humanities is highly beneficial. Shortlisted candidates may be asked to complete a brief written screening question and/or an interview.

job_title: Reasoning in the Sciences  & Biology Seminars
application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter, CV, and the contact information for two references to typ.office@utoronto.ca by May 31, 2024  at 5 PM.
duties: The Teaching Assistant (TA) will support the course instructor in the instruction and management of TYP015 (Reasoning in the Sciences), which is a core science course at the Transitional Year Programme at University of Toronto. This course explore aspects of scientific knowledge that are readily applicable in everyday life and in academic settings. These include: fundamental scientific concepts, the processes of scientific inquiry, the scientific enterprise, and key discoveries in the history of science. A theme that runs throughout the course is science as a way of knowing and not the only way. In addition, the TA will also support the Adaptation and Biodiversity and Molecular and Cell Biology seminars (TYP057). These seminars are designed to support TYP students enrolled in BIO120H1 and BIO130H1  to identify principles and concepts of evolution and ecology related to origins of adaptation and biodiversity. The TA will support the course instructor in the general instruction and management of the courses. Duties  include  grading, demonstrating labs,  provide academic support for course assignments, facilitating a variety of tutorials/ study groups, holding consultation (office) hours, invigilating tests and exams, and a bevy of clerical duties related to course management (e.g. updating content on course websites like Quercus). Additional duties will be determined in consultation with the course instructor and registrar. The TA may be required to attend seminars, lectures , and meetings. Please note, this course will be offered in person, with online elements (Quercus). For more information about TYP, please visit typ.utoronto.ca.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: The candidate should be pursuing a graduate or undergraduate degree in a science based discipline. The candidate must demonstrate a commitment to equity and anti-oppressive/social-justice approaches to education and familiarity with Quercus and online instructional methods.
